awd_titl_txt: New Application of Equivariant Index Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
At the scale of atomic physics, the classical laws of physics pioneered by Newton must be adjusted to the laws of quantum mechanics discovered by Heisenberg, Schrodinger, Dirac and others. This process is called quantization. Within quantum mechanics, as within classical mechanics, the laws describing the mechanical systems usually display a high degree of symmetry. This is a reflection of the nineteenth century discovery that symmetries correspond to the conserved quantities like energy and momentum. The symmetry related to the law of conservation of momentum expresses itself in the fact that the laws of physics are presumed to be the same everywhere in the universe. In this project the principal investigator will use noncommutative geometry tools such as equivariant index theory to study several interesting problems about quantization involving various symmetries.
 
The principal investigator will pursue three research projects in geometry quantization and equivariant index theory: (1) applying index theory to geometric quantization of various generalization of symplectic manifolds such as Hamiltonian loop group spaces and log sympelctic manifolds (2) geometrically realizing an irreducible representation of a reductive Lie group as an equivariant analytic index on corresponding coadjoint orbit, and studying its restriction to its maximal compact subgroup (3) generalizing equivariant index theory to noncompact manifolds or groups, based on the KK-theory developed by Kasparov.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In geometry, many invariants arise from solutions to systems of partial differential equations on a manifold. For example, holomorphic functions are solutions to the Cauchy-Riemann equation; harmonic functions are solutions to the Laplace equation. The famous Atiyah-Singer index theorem shows that topological properties associated to the principal symbol of the operator pose significant restrictions on the dimension of the kernel of the linear operator associated to the system of PDEs. When the manifold is equipped with a group action, the resulted equivariant index theorem has many more theoretical connection with non-commutative geometry, representation theory, symplectic geometry etc. In this award, the principal investigator worked on three research projects in equivariant index theory: (1) generalizing equivariant index theory to noncompact manifolds or groups, based on the KK-theory developed by Kasparov; (2) geometrically realizing an irreducible representation of a reductive Lie group as an equivariant analytic index on corresponding coadjoint orbit, and studying its restriction to its maximal compact subgroup; (3) applying index theory to geometric quantization of various generalization of symplectic manifolds such as Hamiltonian loop group spaces and log sympelctic manifolds.

Various generalization of equivariant index theorem arise naturally from many different areas of mathematics, including the Baum-Connes conjecture in noncommutative geometry, Atiayh-Schmid's geometric realization of discrete series representation, as well as the quantization commutes with reduction from symplectic geometry. The PI's construction of equivariant indices play a key role in these pictures, providing new geometric insight to different phenomenas such as Kirillov's orbit method and branching problem in representation theory, and geometric quantization. The PI's interests span a range of subfields from noncommutative geometry to representation theory and symplectic geometry and the PI's  research create unexpected connections between these fields.

During this award period, the PI published 12 papers in high quality jounrnals and few preprint under review.  The PI maintainans active seminar at Washington University in St. Louis and disseminate research results. In addition, the PI gave dozens of invited talks at seminars, colloquia, and international conferences on noncommutative geometry, index theory, and representation theory.
